bioghist.p: Jean-Martin Charcot (1825-1893) was born in Paris, France. He was a professor at the University of Paris for 33 years. In 1862, he began an association with the Salpetrière Hospital, eventually becoming director. His focus was neurology and his work greatly influenced the developing fields of neurology and psychology. He was called "the Napoleon of the neuroses". He was an influential teacher, some of his more famous students being Sigmund Freud and Alfred Binet. He died at Auberge des Settons, near Vézelay, France on August 16, 1893.

scopecontent.p: This is a prescription for treatment of "maladie a Parkinson" written by Dr. Charcot, dated May 4th 1877. The prescription is in French, with a typed transcription in English.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
